comments:
LGST 206 examines the art and science of negotiation, with additional emphasis on conflict resolution. Students will engage in a number of simulated negotiations ranging from simple one-issue transactions to multi-party joint ventures. Through these exercises and associated readings, students explore the basic theoretical models of bargaining and have an opportunity to test and improve their negotiation skills.

Students found the class to be extremely practical and recommended it to any student regardless of major. One student said the class teaches “skills everyone should have.” Students liked the course structure which provides ample opportunity to practice negotiating. Students reported learning a great deal about negotiating and finding the content extremely relevant to daily life.

All students praised Professor Shell, who many named the best professor they have encountered at Wharton. Students commented that he made himself accessible outside of class.

Students reported that there was a great deal of reading for the class and that the grading was “tough.” A few students thought that there should have been more quizzes so there would be less information to recall on each quiz.

LGST 206 examines the art and science of negotiation, with additional emphasis on conflict resolution. Students will engage in a number of simulated negotiations ranging from simple one-issue transactions to multi-party joint ventures. Through these exercises and associated readings, students explore the basic theoretical models of bargaining and have an opportunity to test and improve their negotiation skills.

Students commented on how much they applied what they learned in class in the outside world. Students liked how the grades were not based on the negotiation outcomes which allowed them to focus on learning sound negotiating skills rather than trying to win at all costs. One student appreciated “learning the human dynamics in negotiating than just the bottom line.”

Students praised Professor Taheripour for being “inspiring” and a “natural teacher.” Many noted that she made it very clear that she cared about her students. Students thought that Professor Taheripour did a superb job making the negotiations fun and educational.

Some students commented that the grading seemed arbitrary and that it did not make sense in a negotiation class to have students grade each other.
